orientation.Control Center Operator: Be ready to explain how operations would recognize and declare an incident during a shift handoff.
orientation.OT / SCADA Engineer: Map each SCADA alarm path to who can declare an incident.
orientation.IT / SOC: Tie CSIR triggers to your SOC runbook IDs for quick evidence retrieval.
orientation.Compliance / GRC: Note which phases generate auditable artifacts automatically.
orientation.Incident Commander / Leadership: Focus on when to formally declare vs. monitor and what must be logged.
orientation.Auditor / Observer (read-only): Observe how the training enforces gated progress and evidence of acknowledgement.

scope.Control Center Operator: Operators must know which consoles are BES Cyber Assets and which transient devices are prohibited.
scope.OT / SCADA Engineer: Tie transient device handling to maintenance playbooks.
scope.IT / SOC: Clarify how monitoring tools classify BES vs enterprise assets.
scope.Compliance / GRC: Capture how scope ties to impact ratings in your evidence matrix.
scope.Incident Commander / Leadership: Be able to state who can expand scope during an incident.
scope.Auditor / Observer (read-only): Document how scope answers align to audit requests.

plan.Control Center Operator: Keep the detection-to-declaration timer visible during drills.
plan.OT / SCADA Engineer: Match each plan step to an engineering owner for evidence follow-up.
plan.IT / SOC: Highlight correlation rules that map to CIP-007 triggers.
plan.Compliance / GRC: Note which plan outputs belong in the compliance evidence binder.
plan.Incident Commander / Leadership: Decide when to notify RC/BA/TO leadership per documented timelines.
plan.Auditor / Observer (read-only): Verify the plan references CIP-008 for declaration handoff only.

execution.Control Center Operator: Know what you say vs. what you escalate—never speculate cause.
execution.OT / SCADA Engineer: Stay within documented changes; note evidence capture steps.
execution.IT / SOC: Tie every action to a ticket number and timestamp.
execution.Compliance / GRC: Ensure logs/time sources are synchronized for defensible evidence.
execution.Auditor / Observer (read-only): Capture how roles stay inside script; no improvisation.

etiquette.Control Center Operator: If you do not know, offer to retrieve the log excerpt—never guess.
etiquette.OT / SCADA Engineer: Avoid deep dives into architecture unless asked; cite approved diagrams.
etiquette.IT / SOC: Map answers to ticket numbers to avoid open-ended questions.
etiquette.Compliance / GRC: Frame every answer with time stamps and evidence locations.
etiquette.Incident Commander / Leadership: Model concise answers and defer to SMEs for specifics.
etiquette.Auditor / Observer (read-only): Observe the deferral language and how it keeps scope narrow.

mock.Control Center Operator: Practice short answers that reference the CSIR plan page.
mock.OT / SCADA Engineer: Stick to documented patching/forensics limits when questioned.
mock.IT / SOC: Use SOC alert IDs in answers to show traceability.
mock.Compliance / GRC: Connect each answer to evidence repositories.

quiz.Control Center Operator: Expect scenario questions about declaring incidents mid-shift.

orientation.purpose: Explain what this training is, why CIP-007 CSIR exists, and how it maps directly to audit evidence.
orientation.gate: I understand how this CSIR training flows and that I must follow the phases in order.

topics.title: What is CIP-007?
topics.detail: A standard that safeguards system security management for BES Cyber Systems.

topics.title: What is CSIR?
topics.detail: Cyber Security Incident Response under CIP-007 sets expectations for detecting, declaring, escalating, and documenting incidents.

topics.title: Why auditors care
topics.detail: Auditors verify you can prove detection, declaration, and response steps happened within defined time frames.

topics.title: How this training works
topics.detail: Six linear phases with a final knowledge check and downloadable certificate.

points.title: BES Cyber Asset definition
points.detail: Assets that would affect Bulk Electric System reliability if mis-operated or unavailable.

points.title: Impact ratings
points.detail: Low/Medium/High determine monitoring depth, log retention, and escalation timelines.

points.title: Transient Cyber Assets
points.detail: Vendor laptops, removable media, and field diagnostic tools must follow CSIR entry/exit rules.

points.title: No-incident myth
points.detail: Even if you have never declared an incident, auditors expect rehearsed evidence paths and mock records.

check.question: Which systems require CSIR evidence under CIP-007?
options: Only systems that have previously had a cyber incident
All BES Cyber Systems and supporting tools that could impact BES reliability
Only transient devices when connected to the control center
check.rationale: CSIR applies to BES Cyber Systems and supporting tooling capable of affecting BES reliability, regardless of past incidents.
check.success: Correct—CSIR expectations are tied to impact on the BES, not past incident history.

plan.lead: Phase 2 incorporates the CSIR material from the cip-audit-ready Module 6 content.

steps.title: Detect & declare
steps.detail: Identify indicators, validate against baselines, and document who can declare.
steps.audit: Show detector source, validation notes, and declaration time.

steps.title: Escalate within timelines
steps.detail: Follow role-based timers from detection to declaration to leadership notification.
steps.audit: Clock starts at first credible indicator; keep synchronized clocks.

steps.title: Preserve evidence
steps.detail: Capture logs, screenshots, volatile data, and system notes immediately.
steps.audit: Chain-of-custody, hash values, and who handled the data.

steps.title: Coordinate with CIP-008
steps.detail: If declared, hand off to CIP-008 processes while keeping CIP-007 evidence intact.
steps.audit: Reference the CIP-008 playbook ID, not the full procedure.

steps.title: Return to service
steps.detail: Document recovery steps, validation, and monitoring for recurrence.
steps.audit: Evidence of approvals and validation checks.

plan.note: Every step must show who acted, when, and where the evidence is stored.

shared: All roles timestamp actions with the same authoritative clock.
Record ticket or log IDs for every action and communication.
Never speculate root cause during an audit interview—stick to documented facts.

responsibilities: Recognize operational impacts and trigger declaration per shift guide.
Stabilize the system and avoid unauthorized changes.
Capture console messages and alarms for evidence.
expectations: Know who can declare and who must be notified.
Show evidence of alarms acknowledged and tickets opened.
Demonstrate awareness of transient device rules.
never: Share screenshots without removing non-evidence information.

responsibilities: Validate signals and device health without jeopardizing forensics.
expectations: Map actions to change approvals or maintenance windows.
Align with CIP-008 declaration if triggered.
never: Erase or overwrite volatile data before capture.
Perform vendor updates outside approved steps.

responsibilities: Correlate alerts, validate severity, and coordinate with OT leads.
Document escalation timers and ticket references.
Collect and preserve logs from monitored systems.
expectations: Show correlation rules and alert IDs.
Demonstrate who was notified and when.
Prove monitoring coverage of BES Cyber Systems.
never: Push enterprise tools into OT without change approval.

responsibilities: Ensure evidence is cataloged and retained per policy.
Track decisions against documented plan language.
Prepare audit exhibits and interview briefs.
expectations: Show traceability from indicator to declaration to recovery.
Explain differences between CIP-007 CSIR and CIP-008.
never: Edit technical records without SME review.

responsibilities: Authorize declaration, external notifications, and containment steps.
Protect safety and reliability while directing resources.
expectations: Cite the timer between detection and leadership notification.
Show decision logs and who was engaged.
Demonstrate when CIP-008 was triggered (if applicable).
never: Commit to root cause during live operations.
Skip formal declaration when criteria are met.

responsibilities: Observe that roles follow the script and note variances.
Capture which artifacts prove each phase.
expectations: Recognize the audit trail for each step.
Understand deferral language and when it is used.
Identify any scope or timing conflicts.

rules: Answer only what is asked—no extra systems, no theories.
Use “I will confirm” when unsure; never guess.
State the evidence location and ticket ID instead of storytelling.
Pause, breathe, and defer to the documented CSIR steps.

examples.prompt: What if an auditor asks for a system you do not own?
examples.bad: I think OT SecOps handles it.
examples.good: That system is handled by OT SecOps; I will have their on-call provide the evidence.
We have not completed forensics; evidence collection is underway per CSIR step 3.

examples.prompt: Asked why you did not declare earlier?
examples.bad: We were busy and missed it.
examples.good: The indicator was validated at 09:05 and declared at 09:12 within the documented 15-minute window.

questions.prompt: An auditor asks: who can declare a cyber security incident for a control center outage?
questions.audit: Operators must know the documented declaration authority.

questions.prompt: During a review, the auditor asks for evidence of time synchronization between logs and operator actions.
options: Provide screenshots of clocks and event logs
Explain that clocks are close enough
State it is out of scope
questions.audit: Auditability depends on synchronized time sources.

questions.prompt: You are asked why CIP-008 was referenced but not invoked.
options: Because impact criteria for CIP-008 were not met
questions.audit: Auditors expect rationale tied to documented thresholds.

questions.prompt: Mid-shift, an alarm indicates potential malware on an HMI serving a Medium impact BES Cyber System. What is your first documented action?
options: Validate the indicator, document time, and notify the declaring authority
feedback: Immediate shutdown without validation may create more risk.
Correct—validate, timestamp, and notify the person authorized to declare.
Vendors are engaged after validation and declaration.

questions.prompt: Leadership asks if CIP-008 must be triggered after an event contained within the control center. What is the proper response?
options: Reference the documented thresholds and note they were not met
feedback: Triggering without criteria can create audit noise.
Correct—cite the documented thresholds and decision log.
CIP-008 is not optional when criteria are met.
You should provide the documented rationale.

questions.prompt: An auditor asks where chain-of-custody for collected logs is stored.
options: In the ticketing system with hash values
In a shared drive without access control
feedback: Correct—tickets with hashes and handlers prove custody.
Lack of tracking fails CIP expectations.

questions.prompt: During a mock audit, you are asked to explain why a transient cyber asset was allowed on a BES Cyber System network.
options: Because it followed documented entry/exit checks and logging
feedback: Convenience does not meet CIP requirements.
Correct—entry/exit controls and logging are required.
Verbal approval without evidence is insufficient.

notes: Keep local copies of procedures and checklists for disconnected audits.
Validate time sources before drills and audits.
Store certificates in the audit binder with timestamped filenames.

certificateTemplate.statement: Completed role-based CSIR training aligned to NERC CIP-007 audit expectations.
